title: How much disposable income should i have left at the end of the month to file chapter 7 on a income of 5800.
question: My husband and I make 5,800 a month and our expenses are a month are 5,300. We are in debt over 75.000 and we want to file chapter 7. We have 3 kids and life is getting more expensive now that gas is going up and our teenagers require more expenses. Do you think we qualifiy for chapter 7?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Bankruptcy court,Debt,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Tax law
answers:
Just giving you a simple number is not only difficult, it may not be the correct answer depending on about 30 variables. There are 2 parts to this: 1) The Means Test and 2) your real budget.

Under the Means Test, a family of 5 in Santa Clarita the Median Income is currently set at $87,518. That number changes periodically. You would be more than $1,900 under the median income for purposes of that test and would almost certainly qualify for chapter 7. You don't even take the real "test" part of the Means Test if you are under the Median Income.

However, most courts will also look at the "real budget". As someone answered before, if you have money left over each month, after carefully taking into account all of your real expenses, you would likely have to file chapter 13. A hundred or two is usually not an issue, but $500 per month might be.

I think that you need experience legal advice from a bankruptcy attorney. That attorney can probably help your find that you have underestimated your real expenses and that could lead to relief under chapter 7. Get that advice and make sure you find someone that is experienced.

I agree with several of the prior answers - the answer depends on what expenses you are claiming. Ordinary expenses such as rent, gas, food, etc. Are not going to be the subject of any realistic dispute.

But there are a number of additional expenses that can be claimed that may close the gap. Have your attorney look at the IRS National Standards for a series of statutory expenses such as out of pocket medical expenses, clothing, and even a miscellaneous provision, and increase with the number of people in the household.

This can create several hundred dollars of additional expense that are very difficult to challenge as they have been adopted by the BK Courts and the US Trustees. Website for this can be found here :

http://www.irs.gov/Businesses/Small-Businesses-&-Self-Employed/National-Standards-Food-Clothing-and-Other-Items

You may qualify for a chapter 7, but it's going to be a question of how the math works. You need an attorney to help you with this one.

Do not forget the annual expenses. Insurance, children's school costs, car licenses, as well as monthly expenses that you have not thought about, haircuts, manicure/pedicure (If you are a professional or in sales, you need to look professional)
Maybe. Go see an experienced bankruptcy attorney. Many of us offer free consultations. You will need to sit down and review your entire financial situation.

At the end of the month, you should not have any disposable income. This is because the Bankruptcy Court will likely make the argument that after you pay all of your bills, you still have money left over to pay back your creditors. You may qualify much better for a Chapter 13 in which sets up a payment plan to your creditors to pay off your debt by subjecting ALL of your disposable income towards paying off your debt. It is difficult to say for certain what you may or may not qualify for without knowing all of the information. It would be helpful to consult with a bankruptcy attorney to get a better idea of where you stand.

You have $500 month and over 60 months could pay $30,000 to creditors. So unless your debts exceed $120,000, you won't make the "good faith test" (more information below) and the UST will object to your case. Hope this perspective helps!

Median in California is $87,518 at this point. The income used is gross or before tax income. The vast majority of below median income debtors qualify unless they have extremely low expense or they qualify because the were out of a job an are making really good money right no.

Qualification is just one issue that must be resolved before filing a bankruptcy. You should meet with an experienced bankruptcy attorney that handles chapter 7 and chapter 13 cases. Most bankruptcy attorneys will meet with you at no charge for the initial appointment. You can use the Avvo "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this page to search for an attorney.

You are not supposed to have much of any disposable income left to do a Ch.7. The means test is done on Form B22 and takes into account the number of dependents, IRS allowances, and some of your actual expenses. If you can pay more than $6,000 to $10,000 toward general unsecured debt, over a 5 year period, you often have to do a Ch.13 repayment plan.

Maybe. Based on information provided you may qualify for C7 BK.
More detailed analysis of total living expenses, income, assets and liabilities required.
Consult BK counsel.
